RMP Executive Summary



The City of St. Charles (City), Missouri contracts with American Water Enterprises - Environmental Management Corporation (EMC) to operate and maintain the wastewater treatment facilities. American Water Enterprises - EMC and the City are committed to the implementation of safe procedures for chlorine that is stored and utilized at the Mississippi River Wastewater Treatment Facility (WWTF) in order to protect employees and the community in the event of an accidental release.  

The Mississippi River WWTF stores chlorine in one ton cylinders and the maximum quantity on-site for the Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulated substance is 8,000 pounds. Chlorine is utilized in disinfection of the WWTF effluent discharged to the Mississippi River as required by the U.S. EPA.       

The Mississippi River WWTF has an extensive Risk Management Plan that follows OHSA and U.S. EPA guidelines. Automatic chlorine shut-off valves to prevent the accidental release of chlorine in reportable amounts were installed in 2006. The Emergency Response Plan (ERP) is incorporated into the RMP to ensure procedures are in place to provide for the safety of the employees and general public, as well as the environment and property. The ERP applies to all employees, contractors and visitors. All employees are required to be informed of the necessary actions taken in the case of a chlorine emergency:

?    New employees are briefed in the ERP on the first day of active employment.

?    All employees receive training in emergency actions with an annual review of the ERP.

?    All Emergency Response Team members are trained in accordance with OSHA 1910.120 (q) for Emergency Responders and NFPA Standards for SCBA Training.

?    All First Aid providers are trained and certified by the American Red Cross.

?    All employees are trained in the use of fire extinguishers.

The Mississippi River WWTF has had no accidental release of chlorine in reportable amounts within the last thirty years.

The Mississippi River WWTF has chlorine emergency procedures in place as mentioned above and are documented in the ERP. American Water Enterprises - EMC and the City elect to utilize the local emergency response agency in the event of an accidental release of chlorine in reportable amounts. Representatives of the St. Charles County LEPC conducted an on-site inspection on April 10, 2012. 

The Mississippi River WWTF is in the process of a facility upgrade. An ultraviolet disinfection system was selected and construction has begun to replace the existing chlorine disinfection system. Construction is scheduled to be completed by October, 2012.
